abstract: President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and his Socialist challenger, Francois Hollande, clash in their only televised debate before the May 6 election; candidates attack each other passionately as they try to make their case to the voters; Sarkozy, who is trailing in the polls, could not deliver the clear victory in debate that many analysts think he needed to win the election. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: PARIS -- President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and his Socialist challenger, François Hollande, clashed bitterly on Wednesday night in their only televised debate before Sunday's election, with accusations of lying, calumny and arrogance marking a detailed discussion of French economic and social policy. Mr. Sarkozy trails in the polls, but he could not deliver the clear victory in this debate that many analysts thought he needed to win the election. Mr. Hollande, trying to undermine a reputation for softness and charm, was an aggressive debater, often interrupting Mr. Sarkozy without deference and seemingly even with contempt.

headline.main: France Approaches the End of a Presidential Campaign With a Bitter Debate
